questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about Oracle Data Pump export and import operations? (Choose two.)

choices.A: You can detach from a data pump export job and reattach later.
choices.D: The master table is the last object to be exported by the data pump.
choices.B: Data pump uses parallel execution server processes to implement parallel import.
choices.C: Data pump import requires the import file to be in a directory owned by the oracle owner.
choices.E: You can detach from a data pump import job and reattach later.

discussion.content:
A,E is correct:
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SUTIL/GUID-EBC54840-22B7-486C-B1FD-CAFFB5FC2344.htm#SUTIL871
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SUTIL/GUID-0FD688BF-A25E-40D3-B835-E2CBF069F26E.htm#SUTIL945

D is not correct, there is no master table export, only master table content written to file.

What with B?

Selected Answer: AE
A and E

Selected Answer: AE
Both expdp and impdp jobs are detachable and attachable.
Regarding option B, it's not parallel execution server processes, to be exact "The value you specify for integer specifies the maximum number of processes of active execution operating on behalf of the import job. This execution set consists of a combination of worker processes and parallel I/O server processes."

Selected Answer: AE
Answer is AE.

B is incorrect because parallelism on import process is not related to parallel execution server processes. Task is performed by database writer processes, ie:

Worker 1 Status:
  Process Name: DW00
  State: EXECUTING
  Object Schema: XTP_AC
  Object Name: SYS_C0063284986
  Object Type: SCHEMA_EXPORT/TABLE/CONSTRAINT/CONSTRAINT
  Completed Objects: 1,120
  Worker Parallelism: 1
 
Worker 2 Status:
  Process Name: DW01
  State: WORK WAITING
 
Worker 3 Status:
  Process Name: DW02
  State: WORK WAITING

A & E are correct.

You can both attach and reattach for export and import jobs. 

D is incorrect because at the end of an export job, the content of the master table is written to a file. 

I believe B is incorrect as datapump does not use parallel execution server process for parallel imports by default. We have to specifically provide the parallel paramter during the operation. However, I am not too sure on this rationale. 

I believe we are all in agreement that C is incorrect for obvious reasons.

B & D are correct

Ref: https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SUTIL/GUID-6BDC1CC8-8596-402D-B016-602985B97AB6.htm#SUTIL808

import and export job are both attachable. So A and D is correct (tested 11.2.0.4). But may B be correct, too. 
Confused. If I see this question in exam, I mark AD.

Selected Answer: BCE
SYSKM: TDE wallet operations
SYSBACKUP: All backup/recovery operations

Selected Answer: BCD
Anwser is BCD
SYSBACKUP - This privilege allows a user to perform backup and recovery operations either from Oracle Recovery Manager (RMAN) or SQL*Plus.

https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMQS/GUID-90668C5A-3D99-45E0-BBC0-D2AA98D3F59D.htm

SYSBACKUP privilege encompasses all the privileges required to back up and recover the database. Those privileges are a subset of the privileges included in the SYSDBA administrative privilege.

choices.D: The C # # D_ADMIN user can perform backup and recovery operations for Automatic Storage Management (ASM).
choices.A: The C # # B_ADMIN user can perform all backup and recovery operations using RMAN only.
choices.B: The C # # C_ADMIN user can perform the data guard operation with Data Guard Broker.
choices.C: The C # # A_ADMIN user can perform wallet operations.
choices.E: The C # # B_ADMIN user can perform all backup and recovery operations using RMAN or SQL* Plus.

choices.B: An attempt to start a new session by a user belonging to OTHER_GROUPS fails with an error.
choices.A: An attempt to start a new session by a user belonging to DSS_QUERIES fails with an error.
choices.D: The CPU_WAIT_TIME column indicates the total time that sessions in the consumer group waited for the CPU due to I/O waits and latch or enqueue contention.
choices.C: The CPU_WAIT_TIME column indicates the total time that sessions in the consumer group waited for the CPU due to resource management.
choices.E: A user belonging to the DSS__QUERIES resource consumer group can create a new session but the session will be queued.

discussion.content:
Correct.

https://docs.oracle.com/cd/B28359_01/server.111/b28310/dbrm009.htm#CHDCJCGB

CPU_WAIT_TIME NUMBER=Cumulative amount of time that sessions waited for CPU because of resource management. This does not include waits due to latch or enqueue contention, I/O waits, and so on.

https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E18283_01/server.112/e17110/dynviews_2156.htm
Correct answers are C&E
B should fail too because there is not "OTHER_GROUPS_ resource group (it's OTHES_GROUPS in the display)

comments.content: B is correct , because active session and seq is zero

discussion.content:
Agree with the answers C, D, and F.
– To return the database to the point in time immediately before the most recent OPEN RESETLOGS operation, you use FLASHBACK DATABASE TO BEFORE RESETLOGS.

A is incorrect as Flashback logs are written sequentially, but are not archived.

B is incorrect.
– If the database control file is restored from backup or re-created, all accumulated flashback log information is discarded. You cannot use FLASHBACK DATABASE to return to a point in time before the restore or re-creation of a control file.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about Flashback Database? (Choose three.)

choices.E: Flashback Database can recover a data file that was dropped during the span of time of the flashback.
choices.D: Flashback Database can recover a database to the state that it was in before a reset logs operation.
choices.F: Flashback logs are used to restore to the blocks' before images, and then the redo data may be used to roll forward to the desired flashback time.
choices.B: Flashback Database uses a restored control file to recover a database.
choices.C: The Oracle database automatically creates, deletes, and resides flashback logs in the Fast Recovery Area.
choices.A: Flashback logs are written sequentially, and are archived.

discussion.content: Why not c?
https://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/manageability/emx-intro-1965965.html

A is not correct. Since EM is not available by default after db creation.
We need to enable through dbca .
D is correct.

Answer: D
A incorrect coz, Enterprise Manager Database Express is available only when the database is open

comments.content: A and D are correct the database is open after creation

discussion.content: A is correct

I saw a same question and the answer was different. I guess it was (a)
What is the correct answer for this?

questions.question_text: Which statement is true about Enterprise Manager (EM) express in Oracle Database 12c?

choices.A: By default, EM express is available for a database after database creation.
choices.D: You cannot start up or shut down a database Instance by using EM express.
choices.E: You can create and configure pluggable databases by using EM express.
choices.C: You can perform basic administrative tasks for pluggable databases by using the EM express interface.
choices.B: You can use EM express to manage multiple databases running on the same server.
